title: 110_hr4235
content: The "Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2007" is also known as the Act. It involves the restoration of estate tax and the repeal of carryover basis. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2007 repeals certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, restoring the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to its original state. Sunset provisions are amended to exclude certain years from the Act's application. Conforming amendments are made to related sections. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2007 repeals sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, restoring the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to its original state. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2007 aims to reduce estate tax rates by 20 percent, amending subsection (c) of section 2001 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2007 aims to reduce estate tax rates by 20 percent, with specific tax rates based on different income brackets. For amounts not over $10,000, the tax rate is 14.4%. For amounts over $10,000 but not over $20,000, the tax is $1,440 plus 16% of the excess over $10,000. For amounts over $20,000 but not over $40,000, the tax is $3,040 plus 17.6% of the excess over $20,000. For amounts over $40,000 but not over $60,000, the tax is $6,560 plus 19.2% of the excess over $40,000. For estates over $60,000 but not over $80,000, the tax is $10,400 plus 20.8% of the excess. For estates over $80,000 but not over $100,000, the tax is $14,560 plus 22.4% of the excess. For estates over $100,000 but not over $150,000, the tax is $19,040 plus 24% of the excess. For estates over $150,000 but not over $250,000, the tax is $31,040 plus 25.6% of the excess. For estates over $250,000 but not over $500,000, the tax is $56,640 plus 27.2% of the excess. For estates over $500,000 but not over $750,000, the tax is $124,640 plus 29.6% of the excess. For estates over $750,000 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $198,640 plus 31.2% of the excess. For estates over $1,000,000 but not over $1,250,000, the tax is calculated based on a similar pattern. For estates over $1,000,000 but not over $1,250,000, the tax is $276,640 plus 32.8% of the excess. For estates over $1,250,000 but not over $1,500,000, the tax is $358,640 plus 34.4% of the excess. For estates over $1,500,000 but not over $2,000,000, the tax is $444,640 plus 36% of the excess. For estates over $2,000,000, the tax is $624,640 plus 39.2% of the excess. The amendment applies to estates over $2,000,000 and gifts made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Unified credit increased to equivalent of $3,000,000 exclusion; inflation adjustment of unified credit. The Unified Credit in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the applicable exclusion amount to $3,000,000. Additionally, a cost-of-living adjustment is introduced for decedents and gifts made after 2007, where the $3,000,000 amount will be increased based on the inflation rate. The Unified Credit in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the applicable exclusion amount to $3,000,000 for estates of decedents dying and gifts made after the date of the enactment of this Act in 2007. Adjustments will be made for amounts not multiples of $10,000.
